title: How banks' 'ageism' worsens the plight of interest-only borrowers
text:
0.0001 0.0000 
Almost one million people face losing their homes at the end of their interest-only mortgage, but lenders are doing little to help 
Nearly one million people face having their homes repossessed because they have no plan to pay off their interest-only mortgages, but banks are still refusing to agree sensible repayment options particularly with older borrowers. 
Time (Xetra: 17T.DE - news ) is running out for an estimated 934,000 homeowners who have no way of paying off their debt when their mortgage term ends, according to research by Citizens Advice. 
The charity said they will be forced to sell their properties or risk having their homes repossessed unless they find the necessary funds. 
The new figure is much higher than previous estimates from the City regulator, the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA), which said that around 260,000 homeowners had no strategy to pay off their mortgages in 2013. 
Telegraph Money has written previously about the plight of older interest-only borrowers who have been told they cannot switch to a repayment mortgage because they "cannot afford" the repayments. In many cases, the borrowers are forced into their lender's high standard variable rate, which costs even more. 
Even (Taiwan OTC: 6436.TWO - news ) very wealthy borrowers who have a stable income in retirement are being told they cannot extend their mortgage term to allow them to repay the debt. 
This newspaper is still receiving letters and emails from readers in their 50s and 60s who are in the same nonsensical position and who fear they will lose their home. 
Rules were tightened in 2012 to ensure interest-only mortgages were no longer offered without a repayment plan, resulting in a major drop in the numbers sold. 
But due to previous peaks in sales of the home loans sold to millions in the 1980s and 1990s the FCA has predicted waves of potential repossessions in 2017/18, 2027/28 and in 2032. 
Gillian Guy, of Citizens Advice, said interest-only mortgages had forced many people into a "financial black hole". 
She (Munich: SOQ.MU - news ) said: "It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) is good that rules around these mortgages have changed, but there are many people who previously took out these products and face losing their home. 
"Lenders have to exhaust all other options when borrowers get into arrears. It's time to level the playing field so that interest-only customers get the same protections when their mortgages mature.”

Around 3.3 million UK homeowners have interest-only mortgages. 
The loans were popular because borrowers only had to repay the interest every month, rather than any capital, so regular repayments were considerably lower. However the full debt must be cleared at the end of the mortgage term. 
In 2013 the FCA called on banks to contact all borrowers with interest-only mortgages due to end before 2020 to discuss how they plan to repay, but only 30pc of borrowers responded. 
Citizens Advice said people who already have the loans need more support because they do not have the same protections as other mortgage holders if they fall into arrears. 
Lenders should have to do more preventative work to help customers prepare for the end of their mortgage, such as phoning customers or offering face-to-face meetings, it added. 
The charity said lenders should have to follow steps before taking an interest-only borrower to court, including discussing a range of repayment options, offering an alternative mortgage product, including extending the duration of the mortgage, and allowing enough time to sell their home for market price if necessary.
